Question: So first tell me what exactly is Java and where you have used it
Answer: Java is basically an object oriented programming language and I mostly use it to build backend logic and small applications and it runs on JVM so it works on any system

Question: Ok so when you write Java code how does it actually run in the system
Answer: First Java compiler converts code into bytecode and then JVM runs that bytecode

Question: Why people say Java is platform independent
Answer: Because Java does not run directly on OS it runs on JVM and JVM is available for every OS

Question: Can you explain what JVM actually does
Answer: JVM executes bytecode and also manages memory and handles garbage collection

Question: You must have heard JDK and JRE so what is the real difference
Answer: JDK is used to write and compile code and JRE is only used to run Java programs

Question: If I install JDK do I still need JRE
Answer: JDK already contains JRE so we do not need to install it separately

Question: While coding in Java what basic data types you usually use
Answer: I mostly use int float double char and boolean

Question: In Java everything is object but still we have primitives so why is that
Answer: Primitives are there for performance and memory efficiency

Question: So tell me what is a class in your own words
Answer: Class is like a blueprint which defines what an object will have and what it can do

Question: Then what exactly is an object
Answer: Object is a real instance of a class which we actually use in program

Question: Why Java program always starts from main method
Answer: Because JVM looks for main method first to start execution

Question: Why main method is static in Java
Answer: So that JVM can call it without creating object

Question: When you create object what method is called automatically
Answer: Constructor is called automatically when object is created

Question: Can you tell me what constructor is used for
Answer: Constructor is used to initialize object variables

Question: Can we write more than one constructor in a class
Answer: Yes we can do constructor overloading by using different parameters

Question: You have used this keyword so why do we actually need it
Answer: This keyword is used to refer current object and to avoid confusion between variables

Question: So tell me what is inheritance and why do we use it
Answer: Inheritance is used to reuse code and access parent class features in child class

Question: In simple words what is polymorphism
Answer: Polymorphism means same method behaves differently in different situations

Question: What is the difference between overloading and overriding
Answer: Overloading is same method name in same class and overriding is redefining parent method in child class

Question: Why do we make variables private in class
Answer: To protect data and achieve encapsulation

Question: So how do you access private variables then
Answer: We use getters and setters to access private variables

Question: Have you used interface If yes why
Answer: Yes interface is used when we want to define a rule that classes must follow

Question: What is the use of abstract class in real projects
Answer: It is used when we want to share common code and also force child class to implement some methods

Question: Why Java does not support multiple inheritance with classes
Answer: To avoid confusion and complexity like diamond problem

Question: So how Java achieves multiple inheritance
Answer: By using interfaces

Question: What is package and why we use it
Answer: Package is used to organize code and avoid class name conflicts

Question: When you write static keyword what does it mean
Answer: It means that variable or method belongs to class not to object

Question: So where have you used static in your code
Answer: I have used static in main method and utility methods

Question: What is final keyword and where do you use it
Answer: Final is used when we do not want to change variable or override method or extend class

Question: While running program have you seen errors so what is exception
Answer: Exception is a runtime problem that stops normal flow of program

Question: So how do you usually handle exceptions in your code
Answer: We use try catch block to handle exceptions

Question: What is finally block and when it is useful
Answer: Finally block is used to write cleanup code and it always runs

Question: You use String a lot so what exactly is String in Java
Answer: String is an object that represents sequence of characters

Question: People say String is immutable so what does that mean
Answer: It means once created we cannot change its value

Question: So why Java made String immutable
Answer: For security memory saving and thread safety

Question: What is the difference between == and equals in real usage
Answer: Double equal checks reference and equals checks actual content

Question: When do you use array in your program
Answer: When I need to store multiple values of same type

Question: If you want to repeat something many times what do you use
Answer: We use loops like for and while

Question: So when do you prefer for loop and when while loop
Answer: If I know number of iterations I use for loop otherwise while loop

Question: In loop what is use of break and continue
Answer: Break stops loop and continue skips current iteration

Question: Can you explain what this code will print int a=5 System.out.println(a++)
Answer: It will print 5 because first value is used then it is increased to 6

Question: What will be output of this code int a=5 System.out.println(++a)
Answer: It will print 6 because value is increased first and then printed

Question: Can you tell me what happens in this code int a=10 int b=20 a=b System.out.println(a)
Answer: It will print 20 because value of b is assigned to a

Question: What will this code print String s1=new String(hello) String s2=new String(hello) System.out.println(s1==s2)
Answer: It will print false because both references point to different objects

Question: Explain this code String s1=hello String s2=hello System.out.println(s1==s2)
Answer: It will print true because both refer to same string from string pool

Question: What will happen in this code int arr[]=new int[5] System.out.println(arr[0])
Answer: It will print 0 because default value of int array is zero

Question: Can you explain this loop for int i=0 i<5 i++ System.out.println(i)
Answer: It will print numbers from 0 to 4 because loop runs until i is less than 5

Question: What will this code do int i=0 while(i<3){ System.out.println(i) i++; }
Answer: It will print 0 1 2 and then loop will stop

Question: What error will this code throw int a=10 int b=0 System.out.println(a/b)
Answer: It will throw ArithmeticException because division by zero is not allowed

Question: Can you explain this code if(true){ System.out.println(Hello); }
Answer: This code will give compile time error because Hello is not in quotes

Question: What will happen if we run this code String s=null System.out.println(s.length())
Answer: It will throw NullPointerException because we are calling method on null

Question: Explain this code int a=5 int b=5 System.out.println(a==b)
Answer: It will print true because both values are same

Question: What will be output of this code int x=1 x+=2 System.out.println(x)
Answer: It will print 3 because x becomes 1 plus 2

Question: Can you explain this code int a=3 int b=4 System.out.println(a>b)
Answer: It will print false because 3 is not greater than 4

Question: What will this code print int arr[]={1 2 3} System.out.println(arr.length)
Answer: It will print 3 because array has three elements

Question: So can you explain what exactly happens in memory when you create an object in Java
Answer: When we create an object first memory is allocated in heap then constructor is called and reference is stored in stack and after that we can use that object in program

Question: Many people talk about heap and stack so can you explain how both are used in real execution
Answer: Stack is mainly used for method calls and local variables and heap is used to store objects and when method finishes stack memory is cleared but heap object stays until garbage collection

Question: You said String is immutable so what actually happens if we try to change a String
Answer: When we try to change a String Java creates a new object and old one remains unchanged and reference is updated to new object

Question: So where exactly these String objects are stored in memory
Answer: Strings are stored in heap and there is also a special area called String pool to reuse same values

Question: In real projects why do people prefer StringBuilder over String
Answer: Because StringBuilder is mutable and when we modify string many times it does not create new objects again and again so it is faster and uses less memory

Question: Can you explain garbage collection in your own words
Answer: Garbage collection means Java automatically removes objects which are no longer used so that memory can be freed and program does not crash due to memory issue

Question: So how does JVM decide which object should be removed
Answer: JVM checks which objects are not reachable by any reference and those objects become eligible for garbage collection

Question: Why do we need wrapper classes in Java
Answer: Wrapper classes are needed when we want to treat primitive values like objects such as when working with collections

Question: You might have heard autoboxing so can you explain what problem it solves
Answer: Autoboxing automatically converts primitive to object and unboxing converts object to primitive so developer does not need to do it manually

Question: If I ask you when to use ArrayList and when LinkedList what will you say
Answer: If we need fast access by index we use ArrayList and if we do many insert and delete operations we prefer LinkedList

Question: So tell me how HashMap actually stores data internally
Answer: HashMap stores data in key value form and it uses hashcode of key to decide where to store the value in memory

Question: What kind of problems you faced with HashMap in multithreading
Answer: HashMap is not thread safe so sometimes data can become inconsistent if multiple threads modify it at same time

Question: Then how do you solve that problem in real projects
Answer: We use synchronized map or ConcurrentHashMap to make it thread safe

Question: So what is the main difference between HashMap and HashTable in practice
Answer: HashMap is not synchronized and faster while HashTable is synchronized and slower so mostly we use HashMap

Question: Can you explain what Set interface is used for with some real usage
Answer: Set is used when we want unique values only such as storing unique user ids or unique emails

Question: When you want to sort objects how do you usually do that
Answer: We use Comparable when we want default sorting and Comparator when we want custom sorting logic

Question: Can you explain multithreading in simple words
Answer: Multithreading means running multiple tasks at same time so that CPU is used efficiently

Question: What is the real difference between process and thread in practical sense
Answer: Process is an independent running program and thread is a small part of that program which shares memory

Question: So how do you usually create thread in Java project
Answer: We either extend Thread class or implement Runnable interface and then start the thread

Question: What problem does synchronization actually solve
Answer: Synchronization makes sure that only one thread can access critical code at a time so data remains consistent

Question: Have you heard about deadlock so what exactly happens in that case
Answer: Deadlock happens when two threads wait for each other resources and none of them can continue

Question: So how can you avoid deadlock in your code
Answer: We can avoid deadlock by proper ordering of locks and by not holding multiple locks unnecessarily

Question: Can you explain exception hierarchy in Java in simple way
Answer: All exceptions come under Throwable and then we have Exception and Error and under Exception we have checked and unchecked exceptions

Question: In real projects when do you use throws keyword
Answer: We use throws when we want to pass exception responsibility to the calling method

Question: Then why do we use throw keyword
Answer: Throw is used when we want to manually create and send an exception in code

Question: People ask about final finally and finalize so can you explain it in simple way
Answer: Final is used for restriction finally is used with try catch and finalize is a method called before object is removed

Question: Have you used marker interface If yes what is the idea behind it
Answer: Marker interface does not have methods but it gives special information to JVM like Serializable

Question: If I copy one object into another what exactly happens
Answer: If we do shallow copy only reference is copied and if we do deep copy then actual object data is copied

Question: So what is the real use of clone method
Answer: Clone method is used to create a copy of existing object without writing much code

Question: Why volatile keyword is used in multithreading
Answer: Volatile makes sure that value is always read from main memory and not from thread local cache

Question: What is enum and where have you used it
Answer: Enum is used when we have fixed set of values such as status or roles in application

Question: Why do we use static block sometimes
Answer: Static block is used to initialize static data when class is loaded

Question: What is instance block and when it runs
Answer: Instance block runs before constructor whenever object is created

Question: So in your opinion when to use abstract class and when interface
Answer: We use interface when we need multiple inheritance and abstract class when we want to share some common code

Question: Can you explain composition in real project terms
Answer: Composition means one class uses another class object to perform some work

Question: What is aggregation and how is it different from composition
Answer: Aggregation is a weak relationship where objects can exist independently

Question: Have you ever seen ConcurrentModificationException so why it happens
Answer: It happens when we modify collection while iterating using normal iterator

Question: So how do you avoid that exception
Answer: We can use iterator remove method or use concurrent collections

Question: Why Optional class was introduced in Java
Answer: Optional is used to avoid NullPointerException and force developer to handle null properly

Question: Have you used Stream API so what benefit it gives
Answer: Stream API makes code cleaner and helps in processing collection data in functional style

Question: Can you explain what will happen in this code List list=new ArrayList list.add(1) list.add(1.5) System.out.println(list)
Answer: It will print both values because ArrayList stores Object type and allows mixed data types

Question: What will be output of this code String s=hello s.concat(world) System.out.println(s)
Answer: It will print hello because String is immutable and concat creates new object but reference is not changed

Question: Explain this code StringBuilder sb=new StringBuilder(hi) sb.append(bye) System.out.println(sb)
Answer: It will print hibye because StringBuilder is mutable and modifies same object

Question: What will happen in this code int arr[]=new int[3] arr[5]=10 System.out.println(arr[0])
Answer: It will throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException because index 5 does not exist

Question: Can you explain this code try{ int a=10 int b=0 System.out.println(a/b) } catch(Exception e){ System.out.println(error) }
Answer: It will print error because exception occurs and catch block handles it

Question: What will be output of this code Integer a=100 Integer b=100 System.out.println(a==b)
Answer: It will print true because small integers are cached by JVM

Question: What will be output of this code Integer a=200 Integer b=200 System.out.println(a==b)
Answer: It will print false because values outside cache range create different objects

Question: Explain this code static{ System.out.println(hello); } main method prints nothing
Answer: It will print hello because static block runs when class is loaded before main

Question: What will happen in this code class Test{ Test(){ this(); } }
Answer: It will cause infinite constructor call and result in StackOverflowError

Question: Explain this code Object o=new String(hi) System.out.println(o instanceof String)
Answer: It will print true because object is actually holding String

Question: What will be output of this code for(int i=0;i<3;i++){ } System.out.println(i)
Answer: It will give compile error because i is not visible outside loop

Question: Explain this code List list=new ArrayList list.add(null) list.add(null) System.out.println(list.size())
Answer: It will print 2 because list allows multiple null values

Question: What will happen in this code Map map=new HashMap map.put(null 1) map.put(null 2) System.out.println(map.size())
Answer: It will print 1 because HashMap allows only one null key

Question: Explain this code try{ System.exit(0); } finally{ System.out.println(end); }
Answer: Finally will not run because JVM exits before it can execute

Question: What will be output of this code String s1=hello String s2=s1 s2=world System.out.println(s1)
Answer: It will print hello because changing s2 reference does not change s1

Question: Your application is getting OutOfMemoryError so how will you start debugging this
Answer: First I will check which area is running out of memory then I will analyze heap dump and see which objects are growing and then I will check why those objects are not getting released and fix the reference issue

Question: What exactly happens inside JVM when a method is called
Answer: When a method is called a new stack frame is created in stack and local variables are stored there and when method finishes that stack frame is removed

Question: If garbage collection is automatic then why do memory leaks still happen
Answer: Memory leaks happen when objects are still referenced even though we do not need them so garbage collector cannot remove them

Question: How do you decide whether to use strong reference or weak reference
Answer: If object must stay in memory I use strong reference and if it is cache like data then I use weak reference so GC can remove it

Question: Your HashMap is behaving slow when data grows so what can be the reason
Answer: It can be because of too many collisions or bad hashcode implementation or frequent resizing

Question: What actually happens when HashMap resizes
Answer: When HashMap reaches threshold it creates a bigger array and rehashes all existing entries which is costly operation

Question: Why is it dangerous to override equals without overriding hashCode
Answer: If both are not consistent then HashMap and HashSet will not work correctly and data may not be found

Question: In multithreading project how do you decide what code should be synchronized
Answer: Only the critical section which modifies shared data should be synchronized to avoid performance issues

Question: If synchronization is slowing down your program what alternatives can you think of
Answer: We can use concurrent collections atomic classes or reduce lock scope

Question: Can you explain what happens in deadlock situation with simple example
Answer: Thread A holds lock one and waits for lock two and Thread B holds lock two and waits for lock one so both wait forever

Question: How do you detect deadlock in running application
Answer: We can use thread dump and analyze blocked threads or use monitoring tools

Question: What is difference between notify and notifyAll in real usage
Answer: Notify wakes one waiting thread and notifyAll wakes all waiting threads which is safer in complex systems

Question: Why double checked locking was broken earlier and how it is fixed now
Answer: Earlier because of instruction reordering it was unsafe but with volatile keyword it works correctly now

Question: What is happens before relationship in multithreading
Answer: It guarantees that changes made by one thread are visible to another thread in correct order

Question: When do you prefer Runnable over Thread class
Answer: We prefer Runnable because Java does not support multiple inheritance and it separates task from thread

Question: Your CPU usage is high but memory is fine so what kind of issues you will suspect
Answer: I will suspect infinite loops busy waiting or too many threads doing active work

Question: What is thread starvation and how it happens
Answer: Thread starvation happens when some threads never get CPU time because other threads always take priority

Question: Can you explain difference between synchronized and ReentrantLock
Answer: Synchronized is simpler but ReentrantLock gives more control like try lock and fairness option

Question: Why wait and notify must be called inside synchronized block
Answer: Because they work on object monitor and without lock it will throw exception

Question: What is class loader and why it is important
Answer: Class loader loads classes into JVM and it helps in security and separation of namespaces

Question: Your application works locally but fails in server so what could be class loading issue
Answer: It can be because of different versions of libraries or classpath conflict

Question: What is reflection and why it should be used carefully
Answer: Reflection allows accessing private data and methods at runtime and it is slow and can break encapsulation

Question: Have you faced performance issue due to excessive object creation so how did you fix it
Answer: We reduced object creation by reusing objects and using pooling where possible

Question: Why immutable objects are automatically thread safe
Answer: Because their state never changes so multiple threads can use them without synchronization

Question: What problem does ThreadLocal solve in real applications
Answer: ThreadLocal gives each thread its own copy of variable so no synchronization is needed

Question: What is difference between fail fast and fail safe iterator in practice
Answer: Fail fast throws exception on modification and fail safe works on copy so it does not throw exception

Question: What happens if exception is thrown inside static block
Answer: Class will fail to load and program may crash

Question: How do you design custom exception and when do you use it
Answer: We create custom exception when we want to represent business specific error and handle it properly

Question: What is difference between shallow copy and deep copy in real bugs
Answer: Shallow copy causes shared data issue while deep copy creates independent objects

Question: What happens if two objects refer to each other and no one else refers them
Answer: Garbage collector can still remove them because it checks reachability not reference count

Question: Why finalize method is considered dangerous and not reliable
Answer: Because there is no guarantee when it will run and it can delay garbage collection

Question: What is memory visibility problem in multithreading
Answer: One thread changes value but other thread cannot see it because of CPU cache

Question: How volatile solves memory visibility problem
Answer: Volatile forces read and write from main memory so all threads see updated value

Question: What is difference between Callable and Runnable
Answer: Callable can return result and throw exception while Runnable cannot

Question: Your program hangs sometimes but no error is shown so how will you debug it
Answer: I will take thread dump and check blocked threads and deadlock situation

Question: What is difference between composition and inheritance in design decisions
Answer: Composition is more flexible and avoids tight coupling while inheritance is rigid

Question: Why we say favor composition over inheritance
Answer: Because composition allows changing behavior at runtime and reduces dependency

Question: What happens if hashCode always returns same value
Answer: All entries go into same bucket and HashMap becomes very slow like linked list

Question: What is happens if equals is slow and used in HashMap operations
Answer: HashMap operations become slow because equals is called frequently during lookup

Question: If you had to explain JVM to a junior what will you focus on
Answer: I will explain memory areas class loading garbage collection and how code actually runs

Question: What will happen in this code class Test{ static{ int a=10/0; } } when you run it
Answer: Class will fail to load and program will throw ExceptionInInitializerError

Question: Explain this code public static void main(String[] args){ try{ return; } finally{ System.out.println(end); } }
Answer: It will print end because finally always executes even if return is called

Question: What will happen in this code class A{ A(){ foo(); } void foo(){ System.out.println(test); } int test=10; }
Answer: It will print 0 because instance variables are not initialized yet when constructor runs

Question: Explain this code Map map=new HashMap map.put(new String(abc) 1) map.put(new String(abc) 2) System.out.println(map.size())
Answer: It will print 1 because equals and hashCode treat both keys as same

Question: What will happen in this code if two threads modify same HashMap at same time
Answer: It can cause data corruption or infinite loop because HashMap is not thread safe

Question: Explain this code volatile boolean flag=true while(flag){ } in multithreading context
Answer: Thread will not cache value and will always read latest value from memory

Question: What will happen in this code ExecutorService service=Executors.newSingleThreadExecutor service.submit(task) service.shutdownNow
Answer: Task may stop immediately because shutdownNow interrupts running thread

Question: Explain this code synchronized(this){ synchronized(this){ } }
Answer: It will not deadlock because same thread can acquire same lock multiple times

Question: What will happen in this code Object o=new Object synchronized(o){ o.wait(); }
Answer: Thread will go into waiting state and release the lock

Question: Explain this code Object o=new Object o.wait()
Answer: It will throw IllegalMonitorStateException because wait must be called inside synchronized block

Question: What will happen in this code Thread t=new Thread t.start t.start
Answer: It will throw IllegalThreadStateException because thread cannot be started twice

Question: Explain this code class Test{ public void finalize(){ System.out.println(clean); } }
Answer: There is no guarantee when or if finalize will be called by JVM

Question: What will happen in this code List list=Collections.unmodifiableList(new ArrayList()) list.add(1)
Answer: It will throw UnsupportedOperationException because list is read only

Question: Explain this code class A{ static int x=10; static{ x=20; } }
Answer: Final value of x will be 20 because static block runs after variable initialization

Question: What will happen in this code String s=new String(hi) s.intern()
Answer: It will put string in string pool but s will still point to heap object
